title: 112_s1984
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protect our Kids Act of 2011". Deaths from child abuse and neglect are preventable and significantly underreported. In fiscal year 2009, approximately 1,770 children in the United States died from child abuse and neglect, with experts believing the actual number to be higher. Nearly half of these children were under the age of 1, and over 80 percent were under the age of 4. Neglect accounted for nearly 36 percent of these deaths, while physical abuse caused 23 percent. Approximately 6,000,000 children in the United States are referred to child protective services each year due to allegations of abuse and neglect. More than 36 percent of deaths from child abuse and neglect are caused by multiple forms of maltreatment. Understanding these deaths can help improve agency systems to protect children. Establishment of Commission. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities is established with 12-15 members appointed by the President, each with experience in various areas related to child welfare and mental health. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities is established with members having expertise in child psychology, emergency medicine, forensic pathology, social work, academia, law enforcement, civil law, and criminal law related to child abuse and neglect matters. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities requires members with expertise in criminal law, substance abuse treatment, education, epidemiology, and computer science/software engineering with a background in interoperability standards. Members must have experience in each of these areas. The Commission members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment and serve for the Commission's lifespan. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission's first meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and the President selects the Chairperson from among the members. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on reducing fatalities from child abuse and neglect in the United States. This study includes examining the incidence of such fatalities, the feasibility of accurately recording incidents, preventative practices, and the impact of parental substance abuse, mental health issues, and domestic violence on child abuse rates. The Commission will evaluate programs for child health, mental health, protective services, welfare, education, child care, juvenile justice, and law enforcement to prevent intentional or negligent child fatalities. They will also assess the effectiveness of policies for collecting accurate data on child fatalities at federal, state, and local levels. The Commission will assess the adequacy of efforts to distribute trained personnel for child welfare services, mental health services, and law enforcement to prevent child fatalities. They will also identify resource limitations and best practices for evaluating programs to prevent child abuse. The curr_chunk discusses programs for preventing child abuse and neglect, prioritizing services for families in need, the correlation between animal abuse and child abuse, and improving data collection methods. The curr_chunk focuses on identifying best practices for promoting child welfare, national standards for training child welfare workers, the potential impact of a Federal law on reviewing child fatalities, and developing a model protocol for coordinating legal proceedings between child protection and law enforcement agencies. The curr_chunk discusses potential strategies to reduce child abuse and neglect, including a public education campaign, modifications to confidentiality laws, improving child welfare outcomes, expanding data sources beyond fatalities, and developing guidelines for tracking instances to improve child welfare. The Commission will review current research and documentation to identify lessons and solutions for reducing fatalities from child abuse and neglect, including tracking instances to improve child welfare. The Commission will work with graduate and doctoral students and institutions of higher education to support its research. It will develop recommendations for a national strategy to reduce child abuse and neglect fatalities and submit a detailed report to the President and Congress within 3 years. The Commission will provide findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The report will be accessible online through the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission may hold hearings at various locations to examine policies and resources affecting child abuse fatalities. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts or donations. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on their status as federal government employees or not, with non-government members receiving a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Government members will serve without additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The compensation for these positions can be determined by the Chairperson without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will terminate either 90 days after submitting its report or 3 years after its initial meeting. The President can extend the termination by 1 year. Federal agencies must respond to recommendations within 6 months of the report submission. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for $2,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2012-2014 to the Commission, with funds available indefinitely.
